elements.content: 1D, 2D, and 3D three metal−organic hybrid frameworks of MgII have been synthesized using 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3idc) with control of the temperature and stoichiometry in a hydrothermal technique. All of the frameworks show high thermal stability, and frameworks 1D and 3D provide highly hydrophilic pore surfaces, correlated by the selective sorption of water molecules over the organic vapor and other gases like N2 and CO2.
elements.clean_text: 1D, 2D, and 3D three metal-organic hybrid frameworks of MgII have been synthesized using 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3idc) with control of the temperature and stoichiometry in a hydrothermal technique. All of the frameworks show high thermal stability, and frameworks 1D and 3D provide highly hydrophilic pore surfaces, correlated by the selective sorption of water molecules over the organic vapor and other gases like N2 and CO2.

elements.content: 1D {[Mg(Hidc)(H2O)2]·1.5H2O} n (1), 2D [Mg(Hidc)(H2O)] n (2), and 3D {[Mg3(idc)2(H2O)5]·2H2O} n (3) metal−organic hybrid frameworks have been synthesized using MgII and 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3idc) with control of the temperature, stoichiometry, and pH in a hydrothermal technique. Frameworks 1 and 3 provide highly hydrophilic pore surfaces, correlated by the selective sorption of water molecules over the organic vapors and other gases like N2 and CO2.
elements.clean_text: 1D {[Mg(Hidc)(H2O)2]⋅1.5H2O} n  (1), 2D [Mg(Hidc)(H2O)] n  (2), and 3D {[Mg3(idc)2(H2O)5]⋅2H2O} n  (3) metal-organic hybrid frameworks have been synthesized using MgII and 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3idc) with control of the temperature, stoichiometry, and pH in a hydrothermal technique. Frameworks 1 and 3 provide highly hydrophilic pore surfaces, correlated by the selective sorption of water molecules over the organic vapors and other gases like N2 and CO2.

elements.content: Recent years have witnessed an explosion in the synthesis of versatile metal−organic hybrid frameworks with different functionality, exploiting the bridging potential of different organic linkers and geometry of the metal ions. Hybrid solids with different topology and dimensionality constructed from the same building unit provide versatile functionality. For the desired framework and functionality in a hybrid solid, it is important to control and understand the external factors, such as pH, temperature, and solvent, that govern the crystallization process and the stability of the overall crystals. Cheetham et al. reported the temperature-controlled different dimensionality and topology in a cobalt succinate system. Later on, Stock et al., Li et al., and others showed that the high reaction temperature and pH increase the dimensionality and formation of M−O−M linkages. Recently, 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3idc) and 3,5-pyrazoledicarboxylic acid (H3pdc) were used to synthesize various functional metal−organic hybrid frameworks. Both ligands have three pH-dependent abstractable protons and six donor sites, which can be exploited for the synthesis of a variety of hybrid solids through a number of flexible binding modes. Of more significance, the spatial disposition of the two N atoms in H3idc with a N−X−N angle of about 144° (X = center of the imide ring), similar to the Si−O−Si angle in zeolite, may provide a porous zeolite-like network. Moreover, porous solids with alkali or alkaline-earth metals are attractive because of their small density, and that makes them potential candidates for hydrogen and methane storage materials. Among the s-block metals, the large polarizing power of MgII can provide a strong coordination bond with oxygen, and there are very few porous hybrid frameworks based on MgII that have been reported. In this Communication, we report temperature- and stoichiometry-controlled hydrothermal syntheses (Scheme ), structural characterizations, and porous properties of three lightweight hybrid frameworks, 1D {[Mg(Hidc)(H2O)2]·1.5H2O} n (1), 2D [Mg(Hidc)(H2O)] n (2), and 3D {[Mg3(idc)2(H2O)5]·2H2O} n (3) (H3idc = 4, 5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid).
elements.clean_text: Recent years have witnessed an explosion in the synthesis of versatile metal-organic hybrid frameworks with different functionality, exploiting the bridging potential of different organic linkers and geometry of the metal ions. Hybrid solids with different topology and dimensionality constructed from the same building unit provide versatile functionality. For the desired framework and functionality in a hybrid solid, it is important to control and understand the external factors, such as pH, temperature, and solvent, that govern the crystallization process and the stability of the overall crystals. Cheetham et al. reported the temperature-controlled different dimensionality and topology in a cobalt succinate system. Later on, Stock et al., Li et al., and others showed that the high reaction temperature and pH increase the dimensionality and formation of M-O-M linkages. Recently, 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3idc) and 3,5-pyrazoledicarboxylic acid (H3pdc) were used to synthesize various functional metal-organic hybrid frameworks. Both ligands have three pH-dependent abstractable protons and six donor sites, which can be exploited for the synthesis of a variety of hybrid solids through a number of flexible binding modes. Of more significance, the spatial disposition of the two N atoms in H3idc with a N-X-N angle of about 144° (X = center of the imide ring), similar to the Si-O-Si angle in zeolite, may provide a porous zeolite-like network. Moreover, porous solids with alkali or alkaline-earth metals are attractive because of their small density, and that makes them potential candidates for hydrogen and methane storage materials. Among the s-block metals, the large polarizing power of MgII can provide a strong coordination bond with oxygen, and there are very few porous hybrid frameworks based on MgII that have been reported. In this Communication, we report temperature- and stoichiometry-controlled hydrothermal syntheses (Scheme ), structural characterizations, and porous properties of three lightweight hybrid frameworks, 1D {[Mg(Hidc)(H2O)2]⋅1.5H2O} n  (1), 2D [Mg(Hidc)(H2O)] n  (2), and 3D {[Mg3(idc)2(H2O)5]⋅2H2O} n  (3) (H3idc = 4, 5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid).

elements.content: IR spectra of 1−3 () show broad bands in the region of 3100−3500 cm−1, suggesting the presence of H2O molecules. The νsym(CO2) was observed at lower frequencies, 1410−1505 cm−1, with a Δν value of 95−100 cm−1 indicating the bidentate chelate coordination mode of Hidc/idc in 1−3.
elements.clean_text: IR spectra of 1-3 () show broad bands in the region of 3100-3500 cm-1, suggesting the presence of H2O molecules. The νsym(CO2) was observed at lower frequencies, 1410-1505 cm-1, with a Δν value of 95-100 cm-1 indicating the bidentate chelate coordination mode of Hidc/idc in 1-3.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group, and structural determination reveals a 1D coordination chain of MgII linked by Hidc (Figure a). In the chain, each Hidc ligand chelated to two MgII centers via N1,O4 and O3,O5 and the octahedral geometry around MgII is fulfilled by the two coordinated water molecules (O1 and O2; Figure a). Therefore, Hidc ligand acts as a dianioinc and bridging bichelating ligand (Scheme ). Mg−O bond distances are in the range of 2.0117(17)−2.1487(18) Å, and the Mg−N1 bond distance is 2.146(2) Å. 1D chains are engaged in hydrogen-bonding interactions with coordinate water molecule O1 and carboxylate oxygens O5 and O6 [O1···O6 = 2.958(2) Å and O1···O5 = 3.038(2) Å], forming a 2D supramolecular sheet in the bc plane (). 2D sheets are further linked by hydrogen bonds through uncoordinated imidazole nitrogen N2 and the pendent carboxylate oxygen O6 [N1···O6 = 2.785(2) Å], forming a 3D surpramolecular framework with 1D channels occupied by the water molecules along the crystallographic c axis (Figure a). The guest water molecules are hydrogen-bonded to each other [O7···O8 = 2.819(2) Å] and further connected with the coordinated water molecule O2, forming a cyclic hexagonal arrangement of the water molecules (). The void space was calculated using PLATON, suggesting a 12.9% void volume to the total crystal volume; however, this would be increased to 29.6% after removal of the coordinated water molecules. The effective hexagonal pore size considering the van der Waals radii is 4.5 × 4.5 Å2 ().
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group, and structural determination reveals a 1D coordination chain of MgII linked by Hidc (Figure a). In the chain, each Hidc ligand chelated to two MgII centers via N1,O4 and O3,O5 and the octahedral geometry around MgII is fulfilled by the two coordinated water molecules (O1 and O2; Figure a). Therefore, Hidc ligand acts as a dianioinc and bridging bichelating ligand (Scheme ). Mg-O bond distances are in the range of 2.0117(17)-2.1487(18) Å, and the Mg-N1 bond distance is 2.146(2) Å. 1D chains are engaged in hydrogen-bonding interactions with coordinate water molecule O1 and carboxylate oxygens O5 and O6 [O1⋅⋅⋅O6 = 2.958(2) Å and O1⋅⋅⋅O5 = 3.038(2) Å], forming a 2D supramolecular sheet in the bc plane (). 2D sheets are further linked by hydrogen bonds through uncoordinated imidazole nitrogen N2 and the pendent carboxylate oxygen O6 [N1⋅⋅⋅O6 = 2.785(2) Å], forming a 3D surpramolecular framework with 1D channels occupied by the water molecules along the crystallographic c axis (Figure a). The guest water molecules are hydrogen-bonded to each other [O7⋅⋅⋅O8 = 2.819(2) Å] and further connected with the coordinated water molecule O2, forming a cyclic hexagonal arrangement of the water molecules (). The void space was calculated using PLATON, suggesting a 12.9% void volume to the total crystal volume; however, this would be increased to 29.6% after removal of the coordinated water molecules. The effective hexagonal pore size considering the van der Waals radii is 4.5 × 4.5 Å2 ().

elements.content: Coordination environment around MgII in (a) 1 (symmetry code: a = 3/2 − x, 1/2 + y, 1/2 − z), (b) 2 (a = x, y, 1 + z), and (c) 3 (b = 3 − x, 1 − y, −z; d = 1/2 + x, 1/2 − y, 1/2 + z).
elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination environment around MgII in (a) 1 (symmetry code: a = 3/2 - x, 1/2 + y, 1/2 - z), (b) 2 (a = x, y, 1 + z), and (c) 3 (b = 3 - x, 1 - y, -z; d = 1/2 + x, 1/2 - y, 1/2 + z).

elements.content: Overall structures of (a) the 3D supramolecular framework of 1 with 1D water-filled channels along the c axis, (b) 2D sheets in 2 stacked along the b axis with hydrogen-bonding interactions forming the 3D hydrogen-bonded framework, and (c) the 3D coordination framework of 3 with 1D water-filled dumbbell-shaped channels along the a axis.
elements.clean_text: 2  Overall structures of (a) the 3D supramolecular framework of 1 with 1D water-filled channels along the c axis, (b) 2D sheets in 2 stacked along the b axis with hydrogen-bonding interactions forming the 3D hydrogen-bonded framework, and (c) the 3D coordination framework of 3 with 1D water-filled dumbbell-shaped channels along the a axis.

elements.content: Changing the temperature from 160 to 180 °C for the same reaction mixture of 1 affords compound 2 (), which crystallizes in the monoclinic chiral P21 space group. Structural determination reveals that each Hidc ligand is chelated to two different MgII centers through N1,O2 and O3,O4 and connected to another MgII via monodentate carboxylate oxygen O5, forming a 2D sheet in the crystallographic bc plane (Figure b and Scheme ). Each MgII is coordinated to one water molecule (O1) and fulfills the octahedral geometry. Mg−O bond distances are in the range of 2.037(2)−2.112(3) Å, and the Mg−N1 bond distance is 2.189(4) Å, slightly higher than that of 1. In between the 2D sheets, the coordinated water molecule O1 and imidazole nitrogen atom N2 are involved in hydrogen bonding with the carboxylate oxygen atoms O3 and O5 [O···O = 2.8663(18)−2.729(2) Å; O···N = 2.946(2) Å], forming a 3D supramolecular network (Figures b and ).
elements.clean_text: Changing the temperature from 160 to 180 °C for the same reaction mixture of 1 affords compound 2 (), which crystallizes in the monoclinic chiral P21 space group. Structural determination reveals that each Hidc ligand is chelated to two different MgII centers through N1,O2 and O3,O4 and connected to another MgII via monodentate carboxylate oxygen O5, forming a 2D sheet in the crystallographic bc plane (Figure b and Scheme ). Each MgII is coordinated to one water molecule (O1) and fulfills the octahedral geometry. Mg-O bond distances are in the range of 2.037(2)-2.112(3) Å, and the Mg-N1 bond distance is 2.189(4) Å, slightly higher than that of 1. In between the 2D sheets, the coordinated water molecule O1 and imidazole nitrogen atom N2 are involved in hydrogen bonding with the carboxylate oxygen atoms O3 and O5 [O⋅⋅⋅O = 2.8663(18)-2.729(2) Å; O⋅⋅⋅N = 2.946(2) Å], forming a 3D supramolecular network (Figures b and ).

elements.content: With an increase in the metal concentration, pH, and temperature to 200 °C, square-block crystals of 3 are obtained quantitatively (). Compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group, and the asymmetric unit comprises three MgII centers. Each octahedral Mg1 is attached to one chelated idc via N1,O4 and another idc through the monodentate carboxylate oxygen O4_b, and the remaining three sties are occupied by the water molecules O1, O2, and O3 (Figure c), whereas the octahedral Mg2 is coordinated to the three different chelated idc. Two chelated idc via N2,O6 and O9,O11 and two water molecules O12 and O13 form the octahedral coordination around Mg3. The Mg−O and Mg−N bond distances are in the range of 2.0215(16)−2.124(2) and 2.103(2)−2.1647(17) Å, respectively. In framework 3, one idc ligand functions as a tetradentate ligand and another one acts as a tridentate ligand (Scheme ), forming the overall 3D network. The resultant 3D network contains a 1D channel along the crystallographic a axis occupied by the four water molecules (Figure c). The potential solvent-accessible void volume suggests 4.0% and 26.2% void space to the total crystal volume after removal of the guest as well as the coordinated water molecules, respectively. The dehydrated framework shows an irregular dumbbell-shaped channel with a dimension of 3.0 × 8.6 Å2 ().
elements.clean_text: With an increase in the metal concentration, pH, and temperature to 200 °C, square-block crystals of 3 are obtained quantitatively (). Compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group, and the asymmetric unit comprises three MgII centers. Each octahedral Mg1 is attached to one chelated idc via N1,O4 and another idc through the monodentate carboxylate oxygen O4_b, and the remaining three sties are occupied by the water molecules O1, O2, and O3 (Figure c), whereas the octahedral Mg2 is coordinated to the three different chelated idc. Two chelated idc via N2,O6 and O9,O11 and two water molecules O12 and O13 form the octahedral coordination around Mg3. The Mg-O and Mg-N bond distances are in the range of 2.0215(16)-2.124(2) and 2.103(2)-2.1647(17) Å, respectively. In framework 3, one idc ligand functions as a tetradentate ligand and another one acts as a tridentate ligand (Scheme ), forming the overall 3D network. The resultant 3D network contains a 1D channel along the crystallographic a axis occupied by the four water molecules (Figure c). The potential solvent-accessible void volume suggests 4.0% and 26.2% void space to the total crystal volume after removal of the guest as well as the coordinated water molecules, respectively. The dehydrated framework shows an irregular dumbbell-shaped channel with a dimension of 3.0 × 8.6 Å2 ().

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of all three compounds is shown in . In the case of framework 1, 18.6% weight loss was observed between 50–135 °C, corresponding to the guest and one coordinated water molecule (obsd 18.7%). Then another coordinated water molecule is released at 220 °C (calcd 6.97 wt %; obsd 6.99 wt %) to give [Mg(Hidc)] n (1′). For compound 2, the coordinated water molecule was liberated between 250–300 °C and the dehydrated framework is stable up to 385 °C. TGA for 3 shows stepwise weight loss of the guest and coordinated water molecules in the temperature range of 70−355 °C and dehydrated framework [Mg3(idc)2] n (3′) is stable up to 500 °C. shows powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the as-synthesized 1 and the dehydrated framework 1′, exhibiting changes in peak positions and intensities and the emergence of some new peaks. Similarly, as shown in , the PXRD pattern of the dehydrated framework 3′ shows a shifting of peak positions and the appearance of some new peaks compared to the original 3. These observations suggest that significant rearrangement occurs in the as-synthesized framework of 1 and 3 and ultimately leads to a pore structure with coordinatively unsaturated MgII centers lying on the pore surface.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of all three compounds is shown in . In the case of framework 1, 18.6% weight loss was observed between 50-135 °C, corresponding to the guest and one coordinated water molecule (obsd 18.7%). Then another coordinated water molecule is released at 220 °C (calcd 6.97 wt %; obsd 6.99 wt %) to give [Mg(Hidc)] n  (1'). For compound 2, the coordinated water molecule was liberated between 250-300 °C and the dehydrated framework is stable up to 385 °C. TGA for 3 shows stepwise weight loss of the guest and coordinated water molecules in the temperature range of 70-355 °C and dehydrated framework [Mg3(idc)2] n  (3') is stable up to 500 °C.  shows powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the as-synthesized 1 and the dehydrated framework 1', exhibiting changes in peak positions and intensities and the emergence of some new peaks. Similarly, as shown in , the PXRD pattern of the dehydrated framework 3' shows a shifting of peak positions and the appearance of some new peaks compared to the original 3. These observations suggest that significant rearrangement occurs in the as-synthesized framework of 1 and 3 and ultimately leads to a pore structure with coordinatively unsaturated MgII centers lying on the pore surface.

elements.content: To confirm the permanent porosity and selectivity, sorption analyses were carried out using the dehydrated samples 1′ and 3′. showing sorption of N2 (kinetic diameter, 3.6 Å) at 77 K and CO2 (3.4 Å) at 195 K for 1′ and 3′, respectively, exhibit type III sorption profiles, suggesting only surface adsorption. This may be attributed to the smaller channel aperture after dehydration compared to the kinetic diameters of N2 and CO2. We have also measured the sorption properties with MeOH (4.0 Å) and H2O (2.65 Å) vapor at 298 K, which is shown in and , respectively. Framework 1′ shows a type II sorption profile with MeOH and about 0.18 molecule of MeOH included per formula unit. This is also consistent with the different PXRD patterns with MeOH compared to those of 1′ (). On the other hand, framework 3′ does not uptake any MeOH, which is also supported by the PXRD patterns similar to those of the dehydrated sample (). The H2O sorption profile of 1′ (Figure ) reveals a gradual uptake up to P/P 0 = 0.36 and then a steep uptake up to P/P 0 = 0.54 with a small step at P/P 0 = 0.44. Then this gradually increases with pressure and reaches an amount of 289 mL/g at P/P 0 = 0.95, which corresponds to 2.3 molecules of H2O per formula unit, whereas 3′ shows a gradual uptake of H2O with increasing pressure and without any step and reaches an amount of 142 mL/g at P/P 0 = 0.96, suggesting 2.4 molecules of H2O per formula unit. Both of the profiles were analyzed by the Dubinin−Radushkevich equation, and the values of βE 0 are 9.68 (1′) and 6.92 (3′) kJ/mol, which reflect the adsorbate−adsorbent affinity, indicating that 1′ is rather more hydrophilic than 3′. Stepwise sorption, stronger affinity, and high uptake of H2O in 1′ would be due to the effective pore size, shape, and different adsorption sites, which are unlike those from 3′. In the case of 1′, regular hexagonal 1D channels are aligned with the four unsaturated MgII centers, whereas in the case of 3′, the unsaturated MgII sites are in a more diffused state in the smaller irregular dumbbell-shaped pores. Therefore, in 3′, H2O molecules cannot interact directly with MgII centers, resulting in the smaller uptake. In both cases, structural reversal with water vapor was correlated by the PXRD patterns ().
elements.clean_text: To confirm the permanent porosity and selectivity, sorption analyses were carried out using the dehydrated samples 1' and 3'.  showing sorption of N2 (kinetic diameter, 3.6 Å) at 77 K and CO2 (3.4 Å) at 195 K for 1' and 3', respectively, exhibit type III sorption profiles, suggesting only surface adsorption. This may be attributed to the smaller channel aperture after dehydration compared to the kinetic diameters of N2 and CO2. We have also measured the sorption properties with MeOH (4.0 Å) and H2O (2.65 Å) vapor at 298 K, which is shown in  and , respectively. Framework 1' shows a type II sorption profile with MeOH and about 0.18 molecule of MeOH included per formula unit. This is also consistent with the different PXRD patterns with MeOH compared to those of 1' (). On the other hand, framework 3' does not uptake any MeOH, which is also supported by the PXRD patterns similar to those of the dehydrated sample (). The H2O sorption profile of 1' (Figure ) reveals a gradual uptake up to P/P 0 = 0.36 and then a steep uptake up to P/P 0 = 0.54 with a small step at P/P 0 = 0.44. Then this gradually increases with pressure and reaches an amount of 289 mL/g at P/P 0 = 0.95, which corresponds to 2.3 molecules of H2O per formula unit, whereas 3' shows a gradual uptake of H2O with increasing pressure and without any step and reaches an amount of 142 mL/g at P/P 0 = 0.96, suggesting 2.4 molecules of H2O per formula unit. Both of the profiles were analyzed by the Dubinin-Radushkevich equation, and the values of βE 0 are 9.68 (1') and 6.92 (3') kJ/mol, which reflect the adsorbate-adsorbent affinity, indicating that 1' is rather more hydrophilic than 3'. Stepwise sorption, stronger affinity, and high uptake of H2O in 1' would be due to the effective pore size, shape, and different adsorption sites, which are unlike those from 3'. In the case of 1', regular hexagonal 1D channels are aligned with the four unsaturated MgII centers, whereas in the case of 3', the unsaturated MgII sites are in a more diffused state in the smaller irregular dumbbell-shaped pores. Therefore, in 3', H2O molecules cannot interact directly with MgII centers, resulting in the smaller uptake. In both cases, structural reversal with water vapor was correlated by the PXRD patterns ().

elements.content: H2O sorption isotherms at 298 K (black, adsorption; red, desorption): (a) for 1′; (b) for 3′. (P 0 is the saturated vapor pressure of H2O at 298 K).
elements.clean_text: 3  H2O sorption isotherms at 298 K (black, adsorption; red, desorption): (a) for 1'; (b) for 3'. (P 0 is the saturated vapor pressure of H2O at 298 K).

elements.content: In conclusion, we have synthesized 1D, 2D, and 3D MgII frameworks using the H3idc ligand by controlling the temperature and stoichiometry. All of the frameworks show high thermal stability conferred by the strong Mg−O bonds. The dehydrated 1′ and 3′ exhibit highly selective sorption properties to H2O over N2 or CO2. Frameworks 1′ and 3′ unveil a very strong hydrophilic character, and they may find application in the separation of hydrophilic and hydrophobic molecules.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have synthesized 1D, 2D, and 3D MgII frameworks using the H3idc ligand by controlling the temperature and stoichiometry. All of the frameworks show high thermal stability conferred by the strong Mg-O bonds. The dehydrated 1' and 3' exhibit highly selective sorption properties to H2O over N2 or CO2. Frameworks 1' and 3' unveil a very strong hydrophilic character, and they may find application in the separation of hydrophilic and hydrophobic molecules.

elements.content: Details of the experimental procedure, Figures S1−S13, Tables S1−S6, and X-ray crystallographic files in CIF format for 1−3. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Details of the experimental procedure, Figures S1-S13, Tables S1-S6, and X-ray crystallographic files in CIF format for 1-3. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: Crystal data of 1: C5H9MgN2O7.5, M r = 241.45, monoclinic, C2/c (No. 15), a = 13.9242(4) Å, b = 11.6256(3) Å, c = 12.0761(3) Å, β = 108.240(1)°, V = 1856.62(9) Å3, Z = 8, obsd data [I > 2σ(I)] = 1390, R = 0.0338, R w = 0.0945, GOF = 1.04.

Crystal data of 2: C5H4MgN2O5, M r = 196.41, monoclinic, P21 (No. 4), a = 7.0347(2) Å, b = 7.4802(2) Å, c = 7.3586(3) Å, β = 117.965(1)°, V = 342.00(2) Å3, Z = 2, obsd data [I > 2σ(I)] = 1740, R = 0.0289, R w = 0.0744, GOF = 1.04, Flack parameter = 0.5.

Crystal data of 3: C10H16Mg3N4O15, M r = 505.20, monoclinic, P21/n (No. 14), a = 10.4503(7) Å, b = 16.6457(11) Å, c = 11.4380(8) Å, β = 108.225(3)°, V = 1889.9(2) Å3, Z = 4, obsd data [I > 2σ(I)] = 2310, R = 0.0248, R w = 0.0660, GOF = 1.04.
The size is measured by considering van der Waals radii for constituting atoms.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of all three compounds is shown in . In the case of framework 1, 18.6% weight loss was observed between 50–135 °C, corresponding to the guest and one coordinated water molecule (obsd 18.7%). Then another coordinated water molecule is released at 220 °C (calcd 6.97 wt %; obsd 6.99 wt %) to give [Mg(Hidc)] n (1′). For compound 2, the coordinated water molecule was liberated between 250–300 °C and the dehydrated framework is stable up to 385 °C. TGA for 3 shows stepwise weight loss of the guest and coordinated water molecules in the temperature range of 70−355 °C and dehydrated framework [Mg3(idc)2] n (3′) is stable up to 500 °C. shows powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the as-synthesized 1 and the dehydrated framework 1′, exhibiting changes in peak positions and intensities and the emergence of some new peaks. Similarly, as shown in , the PXRD pattern of the dehydrated framework 3′ shows a shifting of peak positions and the appearance of some new peaks compared to the original 3. These observations suggest that significant rearrangement occurs in the as-synthesized framework of 1 and 3 and ultimately leads to a pore structure with coordinatively unsaturated MgII centers lying on the pore surface.

References

Crystal data of 1: C5H9MgN2O7.5, M r = 241.45, monoclinic, C2/c (No. 15), a = 13.9242(4) Å, b = 11.6256(3) Å, c = 12.0761(3) Å, β = 108.240(1)°, V = 1856.62(9) Å3, Z = 8, obsd data [I > 2σ(I)] = 1390, R = 0.0338, R w = 0.0945, GOF = 1.04.

Crystal data of 2: C5H4MgN2O5, M r = 196.41, monoclinic, P21 (No. 4), a = 7.0347(2) Å, b = 7.4802(2) Å, c = 7.3586(3) Å, β = 117.965(1)°, V = 342.00(2) Å3, Z = 2, obsd data [I > 2σ(I)] = 1740, R = 0.0289, R w = 0.0744, GOF = 1.04, Flack parameter = 0.5.

Crystal data of 3: C10H16Mg3N4O15, M r = 505.20, monoclinic, P21/n (No. 14), a = 10.4503(7) Å, b = 16.6457(11) Å, c = 11.4380(8) Å, β = 108.225(3)°, V = 1889.9(2) Å3, Z = 4, obsd data [I > 2σ(I)] = 2310, R = 0.0248, R w = 0.0660, GOF = 1.04.

In the case of framework 1, 18.6% weight loss was observed between 50-135 °C, corresponding to the guest and one coordinated water molecule (obsd 18.7%). Then another coordinated water molecule is released at 220 °C (calcd 6.97 wt %; obsd 6.99 wt %) to give [Mg(Hidc)] n  (1'). For compound 2, the coordinated water molecule was liberated between 250-300 °C and the dehydrated framework is stable up to 385 °C. TGA for 3 shows stepwise weight loss of the guest and coordinated water molecules in the temperature range of 70-355 °C and dehydrated framework [Mg3(idc)2] n  (3') is stable up to 500 °C.  shows powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the as-synthesized 1 and the dehydrated framework 1', exhibiting changes in peak positions and intensities and the emergence of some new peaks. Similarly, as shown in , the PXRD pattern of the dehydrated framework 3' shows a shifting of peak positions and the appearance of some new peaks compared to the original 3. These observations suggest that significant rearrangement occurs in the as-synthesized framework of 1 and 3 and ultimately leads to a pore structure with coordinatively unsaturated MgII centers lying on the pore surface.

References

Crystal data of 1: C5H9MgN2O7.5, M r = 241.45, monoclinic, C2/c (No. 15), a = 13.9242(4) Å, b = 11.6256(3) Å, c = 12.0761(3) Å, β = 108.240(1)°, V = 1856.62(9) Å3, Z = 8, obsd data [I > 2σ(I)] = 1390, R = 0.0338, R w = 0.0945, GOF = 1.04.

Crystal data of 2: C5H4MgN2O5, M r = 196.41, monoclinic, P21 (No. 4), a = 7.0347(2) Å, b = 7.4802(2) Å, c = 7.3586(3) Å, β = 117.965(1)°, V = 342.00(2) Å3, Z = 2, obsd data [I > 2σ(I)] = 1740, R = 0.0289, R w = 0.0744, GOF = 1.04, Flack parameter = 0.5.

Crystal data of 3: C10H16Mg3N4O15, M r = 505.20, monoclinic, P21/n (No. 14), a = 10.4503(7) Å, b = 16.6457(11) Å, c = 11.4380(8) Å, β = 108.225(3)°, V = 1889.9(2) Å3, Z = 4, obsd data [I > 2σ(I)] = 2310, R = 0.0248, R w = 0.0660, GOF = 1.04.

metadata.title: Temperature- and Stoichiometry-Controlled Dimensionality in a Magnesium 4,5-Imidazoledicarboxylate System with Strong Hydrophilic Pore Surfaces
